awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Prototyping an Adaptive Irrigation System for Saline Water
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project lies in improved understanding of development of smart systems and in potentially significant resource savings. Irrigation with saline water is a complex problem requiring consideration of many factors such as irrigation water quality, soil conditions, plant tolerance thresholds, and weather forecasts. This project will develop a prototype wireless sensor network and a control system that consider sensor inputs, user-defined thresholds and weather forecasts to determine when and where to irrigate. From an economic perspective, implementation of even a single soil moisture sensor in home lawns can significantly reduce water consumption and produce a return on investment within a few months. Cities stand to save millions of dollars by implementing efficient irrigation technology to reduce water use. The proposed adaptive system for irrigation with reclaimed water thus represents a tremendous potential market for more efficient water use.

The proposed project offers a transformative approach for landscape irrigation based on closed-loop control. Landscape irrigation accounts for a majority of urban summer domestic water use; irrigating with reclaimed water has the potential to substantially extend water resources but may pose hazards to environmental and plant health. Existing ?smart? irrigation control systems have proved water-efficient but have limitations and have not been widely adopted. The proposed system is unique in its combination of wireless water and soil quality sensors into an advanced network capable of controlling several critical agronomic variables, while welcoming but limiting the need for human inputs. A team of domain experts in academia and industry will work together to understand the practical challenges and to design such an adaptive irrigation system to address widespread water resource issues. Key contributions of the proposed research are (1) realizing a truly self-organizing ad-hoc wireless irrigation sensor and actuator network that integrates traditional monitoring and stakeholder input for adaptive irrigation control; and (2) testing the efficient and protective delivery of saline irrigation water using the network. Such fundamental and applied knowledge will provide the basis to ultimately realize significant water savings while protecting human and plant health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation

In the arid west, water has always been a valuable resource. Climate change and a growing population have increased stress on water resources. Irrigation, particularly for turfgrass, uses a tremendous amount of water. Reclaimed water, or treated wastewater, represents another potential water source for irrigation. While reclaimed water can be treated to levels appropriate for direct human consumption, less stringent treatment is sufficient for other water-intensive applications like irrigation. However, salt levels are commonly elevated in reclaimed water; the salt may be harmful to plants and may require application of additional water to flush excess salts out of the root zone. Traditionally, turfgrass has been irrigated on a timed system with potable and reclaimed (non-potable) water sources, which can lead to water waste. Recent advances in technology have allowed for wireless smart sensor systems to optimize water use for turfgrass irrigation by relying on in-ground sensors that report when turfgrass needs to be irrigated with potable water. However, real-time salinity detection technology has not yet been integrated into the systems to tailor the use of reclaimed water to meet water needs while keeping salt levels low enough to sustain plant health. This project investigated how sensors capable of analyzing soil salinity in real time could reduce the amount of both potable and reclaimed water needed for turfgrass irrigation while maintaining comparable plant health. To test this, a wireless, smart sensor-based irrigation system was developed at Colorado School of Mines in collaboration with New Mexico State University?s Turfgrass Test Center.

 

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of a smart sensor-based irrigation system using reclaimed water lies in the advancement of technology that allows for detection of soil salinity in real time, which can be used in addition to soil moisture for irrigation system control. Integration of in-ground salinity sensors may provide an option for reducing water needed for irrigating turfgrass with reclaimed water. Key findings in this study were both direct and indirect to the main goal. Directly, optimization of turfgrass irrigation using water with elevated levels of salinity shows that a reduced amount of water can be used while maintaining comparable plant health. Indirectly, for remote, wireless systems to be effective, robust software and minimal energy consumption are required. Wireless sensor-based irrigation systems will likely be deployed in a distributed fashion, where energy from a power grid is unlikely, and therefore a renewable, reliable power source is imperative. Initial hardware in the field consumed more energy than could be replenished in a given day, which led to routine crashes in the overall system. Hardware with more limited energy consumption is needed for such systems to run for extended periods of time. 

 

Broader Impacts

Smart sensor-based irrigation systems have the potential to reduce the amount of water needed for turfgrass irrigation and can use reclaimed waters that may otherwise be limited or wasted, thus preserving potable water supplies. The study also highlights the need for effective distributed energy supply and minimized energy consumption by remote wireless systems to be used for extended periods of time. The results were presented at different academic and industry conferences. The project allowed researchers in multiple scientific disciplines including agriculture, engineering, and computer systems from multiple institutions to collaborate toward a common goal, providing interdisciplinary experience for one graduate student, two research faculty, seven undergraduates, and four principal investigators at two universities and one multi-national corporation.
